message_1: A spaceship is travelling away from Earth at a speed of 0.8c. The spaceship emits a radio signal at a frequency of 1 GHz. What frequency does the radio signal appear to have to a stationary observer on Earth? (Assume the speed of light is 3 x 10^8 m/s)
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the Doppler effect formula for relativistic speeds:

f_observed = f_source * sqrt((1 - v/c) / (1 + v/c))

where f_observed is the frequency observed on Earth, f_source is the frequency emitted by the spaceship (1 GHz), v is the speed of the spaceship (0.8c), and c is the speed of light (3 x 10^8 m/s).

f_observed = (1 GHz) * sqrt((1 - 0.8) / (1 + 0.8))

f_observed = (1 GHz) * sqrt(0.2 / 1.8)

f_observed ≈ (1 GHz) * sqrt(0.1111)

f_observed ≈ (1 GHz) * 0.3333

f_observed ≈ 0.3333 GHz

So, the frequency of the radio signal observed on Earth is approximately 0.3333 GHz.
